advantages: More efficient than binary search for uniformly distributed datasets, with an average time complexity of O(log log n).
Reduces the number of comparisons by estimating the position of the target based on its value relative to the dataset's bounds.
Works well for large datasets where the elements are evenly distributed.
disadvantages: Requires the dataset to be sorted and uniformly distributed for optimal performance.
Inefficient for datasets with a non-uniform distribution or when the values are closely spaced, leading to a worst-case time complexity of O(n).
Not suitable for linked lists or other data structures without random access.
